pros: If you want to work like an entrepreneur with a focus on demand-driven Warren Buffet-style value within the company and not as an employee, great place.
cons: Got burnt out between year 4 to 5. Pace yourself folks.

pros: Amazon on resume and stable stock. You might learn interesting things depending on the team.
cons:
No perks, bad management, lack of innovation.

WLB was good for a while till people had to start running working in the middle of the night and on weekends.

summary: I love it at Amazon. At least most of the time.
pros: It highly depend on the team you are working with. My team is fantastic and the manager is the best manager anyone could ask for.
cons: It's so rigid to the point where we feel like robots. And Day 1 Culture that they brag about has become an abstract concept in the past 2 or 3 years.

summary: Great company to learn operating large scale systems, but low on benefits/compensation
pros: Learn how to operate large scale systems and use other AWS services
cons:
Low benefits/compensation out of all MAANG companies.
Need manager support to grow, otherwise you will find yourself in PIP

pros: Great tech, processes, learning curve and world class corporate culture
cons: Always start up culture and too many layers to cross to create an impact

pros: Compensation, business impact opportunity, working with brightest minds, access to latest and greatest tech and tools.
cons: Day 2 traits like favouritism, reactive planning, perception building etc.

pros: Brand value, Tech stacks, Work culture depends on the team and org.
cons: Slow/no career growth, depends on the org leadership and management, on-call is a pain

pros: Amazon learning curve and good managers and compensation is also good
cons: Work can be bit more as compared to other company

summary: Good career growth but be prepared for pip
pros: Great place to learn n grow , good brand value
cons: Pip factory, everything is fire drill and required on urgent basis

pros:
Work with AWS tech stack 
Internal opportunities 
Large scale system
cons:
Oncall 
Wlb 
Fear culture 
Benefits 
Mediocre  Pay
Bad leadership 
Politics

summary: Good brand to have on resume, reasonable WLB and good initial comp
pros:
Compensation
Resume Builder
Innovative technology and interesting learning curve 
Smart people to learn from
cons:
Lack of rationale leadership decisions 
Lack of communication 
Bureaucratic operations makes change slow and difficult to happen

pros: When I first joined, I had a harebrained idea to containerize our core service. Instead of putting down my idea, my manager asked if I could run it by our senior engineer. No idea got shot down, and if I felt it was worth my time to do something, I could pitch it and get rewarded for doing it.
cons: Amazon is behind in AI use internally, while the world is learning to code with agents you will be coding with tech at least a year old.

pros: If you have a good manager you will have a lot of opportunities to grow as a young engineer. It's not once you reach L6 that things start to slow down
cons: Depending on the time of year work life balance can take a huge hit. Sometimes there are "critical" fires that need to be put out. Since you mostly get paid in stocks your TC can take a huge hit.

pros: A lot of smart and hardworking people to learn from.
cons: Very bureaucratic, it takes time to get many tasks done due to the need for many stakeholders to sign off

pros: If you find the right place you can grow and try things you never could at other places.
cons: The goalposts are ambiguous. When they decide it’s your time, it’s your time.

pros: good if leadership is understanding. my immediate manager is not great so it pretty bad
cons: no benefits, a lot less teams and orgs with good leadership

pros: Compensation is the only good thing as long as the stock does well
cons: Deteriorating culture, RTO mandate, political stack ranking to meet targets

summary: Great contributors held back by toxic leadership and power dynamics
pros: You get to collaborate with highly skilled colleagues to tackle impactful problems, making it a great place to learn
cons: Leadership is toxic and unaccountable. Levelism is rampant and leads to toxic dynamics.

pros: Lots of opportunities, lots to learn and grow. Customer obsessed and problem solving is appreciated
cons: Bad management and firing policy. Focus, Pivot and manager politics is really bad

pros: Lots of smart people and interesting projects to work on.
cons: Really have to advocate for yourself and build strong narratives.

pros:
- good initial salary
- very interesting and unique work
- most individual contributors are great and genuinely smart people being worked to the bone
cons:
- no work-life balance
- absolutely no care for employee health and well-being
- racist middle and upper management. If you aren’t of Indian or Asian descent, your growth opportunities are very limited or non-existent i certain orgs within AWS
- absolute bare-minimum benefits. Literally any competitor has better benefits.

pros: Smart people a lof of things to learn. AWS opens doors
cons: High expectations no acknowledgment . It is really hard to feel appreciated

summary: Good place to start, place is filled with politics and frauds though.
pros: Amazon is good on resumes despite all of its cons.
cons: Managers are some of the worst I've dealt with, projects get delayed due to alignment, people are not that bright here.

pros:
Workload is not crazy
Great visibility to the entire org
cons:
Not much career growth
Lower pay compare to other job family

summary: Ruthless and competitive culture. Comp is reasonable but you have to work super hard and career growth path unclear.
pros: Comp. Stocks. Ability to learn and work on new and different things.
cons: Have to be a high performer to survive cuts. Lack of clarity in career growth.

pros: Occasionally get to work with brilliant minds, considered to be a leader in the industry, looks good on a resume.
cons: No growth or opportunities for highest performers, management not in touch with modern methods or work cultures, lack of focus on highest growth areas, hundreds of "little kingdoms" with significant product overlap and no oversight.

pros: Generally strong engineering rigor in AWS, though can’t say the same about the rest of the company. Coworkers are generally pretty talented and hardworking.
cons:
Experience is very team and manager dependent. 

Lots of top down mandates that make charters unclear. Priorities shift by the week

pros: Work with brilliant and kind people with predicable business cadence.
cons: Very slow moving. Frustrating for product leaders and developers to actually deliver value to customers

pros: Good pay and job growth opportunities. Hard to beat the pay, and with a good manager can be promoted pretty fast
cons: Lots of levels of management, and often tight deadlines that can cause stress

summary: Good growth opportunities but management sucks
pros: Growth opportunities and some really smart people to learn with.
cons: Management is clueless and do not value effort rather cruise and let team fail.
